book.body:
Welcome

Welcome to the eOffer/eMod User Help Center! This site has been designed as a guide to introduce you to the eOffer/eMod system. Throughout this Knowledge Base, you will find a step-by-step approach explaining many specific functions within the eOffer/eMod system, as well as information to provide you with a firm understanding of the system as a whole.

Featured Additions

Below are featured articles we would like to bring to your attention.

page.name: introduction
page.title: Introduction
page.body:
Welcome to the eOffer/eMod User Guide! This guide will introduce you to the eOffer/eMod system, a web-based application designed to make the contracting process efficient and secure. The system allows for seamless transmission of data from the Vendor/Contractor community to the Federal Acquisition (FAS) Contracting Offices. This guide is intended for vendors, but can be useful to Contracting Officers (COs) and Contracting Specialists (CSs) as well.

This Guide was written to give an accessible understanding of the different functions of eOffer/eMod to vendors who use the system to submit contract Offers and Contract Modifications. The guide aims to give a comprehensive and easy-to-understand breakdown of the functions of eOffer/eMod, with helpful hints and important reminders along the way.

page.name: using-the-guide
page.title: Using the Guide
page.body:
The eMod/eOffer User Guide is a searchable and easily navigable manual designed to provide readers with a comprehensive understanding of the eMod/eOffer system. It has also been developed to further the reader's understanding of the contracting process and explain how eOffer/eMod facilitates contracting on the Vendor's side. To continue your learning beyond the information contained in this guide, be sure to consult with your supervisor for additional training opportunities and direction on how to get personalized assistance.

While reading this User Guide, you will notice the following icons throughout:

Helpful Hints: These items provide users with shortcuts or tips on how to better perform a particular action.

Cautions: These items identify potential pitfalls of which the user should be aware.

Key Concepts: These items identify high level attributes or features of a particular program or system.

Things to Remember: These items identify the important points users should take away from a particular section.

If, after searching this User Guide, you still have an unanswered question about the eOffer/eMod system, you may contact the help desk by dialing 866-472-9114 or via e-mail at eoffer@gsa.gov. Their hours of operation are from 8:00 AM to 7:00 PM, Monday through Friday, Eastern Standard Time.

page.name: system-purpose-and-overview
page.title: System Purpose and Overview
page.body:
Under the Schedules Program, Vendors can establish long-term Contracts with GSA that allow them to do business with customers throughout the federal government. In order for Vendors to become a "GSA Schedule Contractor," they must first submit an Offer in response to an applicable Multiple Award Schedule Solicitation. These solicitations are accessible at the Federal Business Opportunities website, (FBO.gov), or, as of 2011, via a link on the eOffer/eMod home page.

Launched in mid-2004, the eMod/eOffer system is a web-based interface allowing Vendors to electronically prepare and submit Contract Offers and Contract Modifications. At a high level, the system allows for an interactive, secure electronic environment that simplifies the Contracting process from Proposal preparation and submission through Contract Award and Closeout.

The eOffer module is available for more than 30 schedules, for example, Furniture (Schedule 71), Office Products and Supplies (Schedule 75), Financial and Business Solutions (Schedule 520), and Professional Engineering Services (Schedule 871).

The eMod module enables Contractors to prepare and submit Electronic Contract Modifications for all GSA MAS Contracts. Multiple eMods may be submitted within a single transaction, allowing for an expeditious process.

The eOffer/eMod system is online at http://eoffer.gsa.gov. Vendors can eSign any Contract Offers or Modifications, but must do so using their Digital Certificates.

The following five characteristics form the core benefits for a Vendor using the eOffer/eMod system:

  • eSimple: User friendly screens lead through the submittal process.

  • eSecure: Digital Certificates ensure the integrity of proprietary data.

  • eSave: Electronic process reduces delivery costs and delays.

  • eShare: Web-based technology facilitates collaboration on Proposal preparation.

  • eSign: Electronic signatures allow offers and mods to be signed quickly and easily.

page.name: accessing-eoffer-emod-overview
page.title: Accessing eOffer/eMod Overview
page.body: eOffer/eMod is a publicly available system; it does not reside behind GSA's firewall. Therefore, eOffer/eMod is available to any internet user via the URL, http://eoffer.gsa.gov/. Having said that, most of the functionality discussed in this Guide involves signing into a secure portion of the website, and there are a few key requirements that need to be satisfied in order for a vendor to actually use the system once signed in.

page.name: system-requirements
page.title: System Requirements
page.body:
In order to ensure the integrity and security of the eOffer/eMod system, four key requirements must be met before a vendor can put the system to use. eOffer/eMod uses the latest digital authentication technology to ensure the integrity of data transmission, and to support the security of electronic signatures applied to Offer or Contract Modifications.

In order to log into the system, the following requirements must be met:

  1. Digital Certificate: A Digital Certificate is an electronic credential stored on the web browser that verifies the user's identity. It is required before a vendor is granted access to the eOffer/eMod system.

  2. Data Universal Numbering System (DUNS) Number: The DUNS number is a unique nine digit identification number assigned to a business entity by Dun and Bradstreet. A valid DUNS number is required to use the eOffer/eMod system.

  3. System for Award Management (SAM): To use the eOffer/eMod system, users must have a DUNS number that is registered in the SAM database.

  4. "Pathway to Success" Training: The final requirement for participation in the MAS Schedules Program is successful completion of the "Pathway to Success" educational seminar.

page.name: digital-certificates-overview
page.title: Digital Certificates Overview
page.body:
In order to successfully sign into the functional areas of eOffer/eMod, a Digital certificate must be present and valid on the user's computer. In basic terms, Digital Certificates are electronic credentials that:

  • Assert the identity of an individual.

  • Enable eOffer/eMod to verify the identity of the individual accessing the system and signing documents.

  • Encrypt or decrypt data to ensure that it is securely transmitted.

  • Store accurate information directly within a web browser or within a token.

  • Create digital signatures that are verifiable.

A Digital Signature:

Is Is Not

  • A piece of information based on both the document and the signer's private key.

  • A digitized handwritten signature.

  • Unique to both the document and the signer.

  • The typed name of an individual

  • Virtually impossible to forge

  • A secret code, password, or PIN.

Key Concept: Each individual accessing the eOffer/eMod system must have a Digital Certificate installed on his or her computer. Digital Certificates are unique to each person and cannot be used by another individual or a group.

page.name: obtaining-a-digital-certificate
page.title: Obtaining a Digital Certificate
page.body:
As previously noted, a Digital Certificate is required before an individual vendor is able to use most any functional portion of the eOffer/eMod system. If you do not currently have a Digital Certificate installed on your computer, the steps below will help you obtain one, and ultimately allow you to begin working with eOffer/eMod.

  1. To apply for a Digital Certificate, go to the eOffer/eMod website, http://eoffer.gsa.gov.

  2. Under the About eOffer menu table, click on the link for Digital Certificates.

    3. Click the Digital Certificates link under the About eOffer menu table.

  3. You will be presented with a page giving you an overview of Digital Certificate information. Under the heading, "How to get a digital certificate," click either the IdenTrust or Operational Research Consultants (ORC) link to visit a Digital Certificates provider.

    4. Select one of the Certificate providers.

  4. For example, if you click the IdenTrust link, you will be taken to IdenTrust's GSA Certification Procurement page. To begin, click 'Buy.'

    Alternatively, if you click the Operational Research Consultants (ORC) link, you will be taken to the ORC homepage. There, you will see an Order button for ACES Business Representative Certificates.

    For either provider, the Certificate purchase process will require proof of employment and two forms of government issued identification.

    5. Key Concept: The information you enter while purchasing a Digital Certificate must match exactly the information that will be used within the eOffer/eMod system. The Certificate application should also be completed on the same workstation that will be used to accept the Certificate.

  5. Whichever Certificate provider you choose, make sure you remember your password! Neither the GSA nor your Digital Certificate provider can tell you what your password is should you forget it, in which case you will be forced to buy another Certificate.

    6. Things to Remember: Your Digital Certificate must be an ACES Level 3 Certificate, (a "Business Identity Certificate"). Without this level of authentication, vendors will not be able to create a legally binding Contract. As noted in this topic, the industry partners who currently provide Level 3 Digital Authentication Certificates for the GSA vendor community are IdenTrust and Operational Research Consultants (ORC). DOD ECA Certificates are acceptable.

page.name: importing-the-digital-certificate-into-your-browser
page.title: Importing the Digital Certificate into Your Browser
page.body:
Once you have received your Digital Certificate, you will need to install it within your web browser. The following are instructions for Digital Certificate installation on Microsoft Internet Explorer.

  1. In Microsoft Internet Explorer, open the Tools dropdown menu and select 'Internet Options.'

    2. Select 'Internet Options' from the Tools dropdown menu.

  2. In the Internet Options window, select the Content tab.

    3. Select the Content Tab.

  3. In the Content tab, click the Certificates button.

    4. Click the Certificates button.

  4. The Certificates window should open with the Personal tab selected as a default; from here, click the Import button. Doing so will launch the Certificate Import Wizard.

    5. Click 'Import' within the Personal tab of the Certificates window.

  5. Click 'Next' once the Certificate Import Wizard launches.

    6. Click 'Next' in the Certificate Import Wizard.

  6. In the following screen, click the Browse button below the File to Import prompt in order to find the Certificate file you wish to upload.

    7. Click 'Browse' to search for your Certificate.

  7. You will have already saved your Certificate on your computer or on another local drive. Navigate to the location of the Certificate and select it so that the name appears in the File name field at the bottom of the window. To facilitate this process, you may use the dropdown menu to the right to filter visible files by the Personal Information Exchange (.pfx) extension.

    Click 'Open' once you have found and selected the correct Certificate file.

    8. Select the correct Certificate file, then click 'Open.'

  8. The field below the File to Import prompt will now show the name of the Certificate file you have selected. Click 'Next' to proceed.

    9. Click 'Next' to proceed once you have selected the correct file.

  9. You must now enter the password you chose when you obtained your Digital Certificate. After you have entered your password, check the security option(s) best suited to your uses, then click 'Next.'

    10. Helpful Hint: Note that you are presented three security options on this particular screen; you may choose any combination of these according to the arrangement best suited to your purposes. For guidance, consult your Supervisor. As a default, in our example we have enabled the third option, Include all extended properties.

    Enter your password, make your security selections, then click 'Next.'

  10. The next screen of the Certificate Import Wizard should default to the option, Place all certificates in the following store, in response to which you will make sure the Certificate store field reads, 'Personal.' If it does not, click the Browse button to select 'Personal' from the available Certificate Store directory. When you have made your selection, click 'Next.'

    11. Be sure the Certificate store field reads, 'Personal.'

  11. The next screen will present a summary of your previous selections. By default, information in the settings window may be highlighted, but there is no information in need of change on this screen. If any of the information displayed here is incorrect, click 'Back' to revisit previous steps. Otherwise, check that the settings are correct, then click the Finish button to proceed.

    12. Click 'Finish' after confirming settings information is correct.

  12. Click 'Okay' when informed that the import was successful.

    13. Click 'OK' after a successful import.

  13. You will now see your Certificate in the Certificates window. Click the Close button.

    14. Click 'Close' to close the Certificates window.

    Helpful Hint: You may return to the Certificates window later on to Remove a Certificate if need be. Or, provided the functionality is enabled, you may also Export your Certificate from this location.

  14. Click 'OK' to close the Internet Options window.

Click 'OK' to close the Internet Options window.

page.name: verifying-information-on-the-digital-certificate
page.title: Verifying Information on the Digital Certificate
page.body:
Once your Digital Certificate is installed and you have backed it up, it is a good idea to verify that all the information is accurate. We are demonstrating this process using Internet Explorer.

  1. In Microsoft Internet Explorer, open the Tools menu and select 'Internet Options.'

    2. Select 'Internet options' from the Tools dropdown menu.

  2. In the Content tab of the Internet Options window, click the 'Certificates' button.

    3. In the Content Tab, click 'Certificates.'

  3. The Certificates window should open by default to the Personal tab. In this tab, you will see any Certificates previously imported into the browser. Select the Certificate whose information you would like to verify, then click 'View.'

    4. Select the Certificate and click 'View.'

  4. In the Details tab you will find a directory containing various Fields of Digital Certificate information. Clicking on these Fields displays the value in the window below the directory listing. To verify the name associated with the Digital Certificate, click on the Subject field.

    5. In the Details tab, click on the Subject field to verify your name.

  5. In order to verify the email address associated with the Digital Certificate, click on the Subject Alternative Name field.

    6. Confirm your email address is correct by clicking the Subject Alternative Name field.

  6. Finally, go to the Certification Path tab to verify the path location of your Certificate.

    7. Verify the path location of your Certificate within the Certification Path tab.

    Helpful Hint: The Certificate status box in the Certification Path tab will indicate whether there are any problems associated with your Digital Certificate.

page.name: system-validation-of-the-digital-certificate
page.title: System Validation of the Digital Certificate
page.body:
Digital Certificates are required by Contractor staff in order to access the eOffer/eMod system. Upon logging into the system, Digital Certificate information is validated against the Authorized Negotiators on a Contract.

To begin, click on the Sign In button under Contract Offers (eOffers) or Contract Modification (eMod). When a user accesses either of the modules, there can be one of several outcomes:

  • The user's digital certificate is validated against the list of Authorized Negotiators on a Contract and the user is granted access.

  • Either the user has never been listed as an Authorized Negotiator because the original Offer was submitted by Paper and thus the user was never added to the electronic system, or the old Negotiator has left the Company at which point they are trying to get a new Negotiator listed in the table.

  • The user was in the Authorized Negotiator list and has either changed his or her name, or gotten a new Digital Certificate without listing his or her details as on the Authorized Negotiator list. Or the person who initially submitted the vendor's information entered it into the system differently than how it was listed on their Digital Certificate.

If the user's login attempt falls into either of the last two scenarios, the system will attempt to validate by using certain combinations of user details. If a potential match is found in the Contract's list of Authorized Negotiators, the user will be able to select his or her information from a list provided, and then submit that information to the existing Authorized Negotiators/Contract Administrators for approval. If the existing Authorized Negotiators/Contract Administrators do not take an action with seven days to approve the new addition, the request is then sent to the CO/CS for approval. The vendor's details are then transferred to the Authorized Negotiators/Contract Administrators, or to the CO/CS, for approval.

The validation combinations include:

  • Last name and email.

    • Validation by last name and email.

  • First name and email.

    • Validation by first name and email.

  • Email only.

    • Validation by email only.

  • Last name and first name only.

    • Validation by last and first name only.

  • Last name only.

    • Validation by last name only.

  • First name only.

    • Validation by first name only.

Digital Certificate Match Found

If the system finds a match using one of the above validation combinations:

  1. Select your name from the list.

  2. Click 'Initiate Request,' which will trigger an email notifying one of the other Authorized Negotiators on the Contract, instructing him or her to submit a modification updating the information of the original Authorized Negotiator. If an Authorized Negotiator is not found, the Request is sent to the CO/CS.

  3. The Authorized Negotiator, or CO/CS, to whom the Request is sent will then log into the system and will be prompted to confirm adding the user to the Contract.

    4. Digital Certificate match found.

Note that if the Authorized Negotiator does not respond with a modification within seven (7) days, the system will notify the Contracting Officer to initiate a modification to update the Authorized Negotiator Data.

Digital Certificate Not Found

If your Digital Certificate is not found by any combination of validation criteria, you will be prompted to complete an application to be added to the list of Authorized Negotiators.

  1. Fill out the fields provided and click 'Submit Request.' Note that the Name and Email fields are pulled directly from the system in order to avoid any typing errors.

    2. Digital Certificate match not found.

  2. An email will be sent to the Authorized Negotiator or, in the case that one cannot be found, to the CO/CS for approval.

    3. An email will be sent to the Authorized Negotiator or CO/CS for approval.

page.name: data-universal-number-system-duns-number
page.title: Data Universal Number System (DUNS) Number
page.body:
A Data Universal Number System, or DUNS number, is a unique nine-digit identification number assigned to a business entity by Dun & Bradstreet. It is required to use the eOffer/eMod system, and also needed when registering with the SAM database. The DUNS number assignment is free for all businesses required to register with the U.S. Federal Government for Contracts or Grants.

Obtaining a DUNS Number

To obtain a DUNS number:

  1. Go to http://fedgov.dnb.com/webform

  2. A Dun & Bradstreet webform will open.

    3. The Dun & Bradstreet webform.

  3. Click the option to request the DUNS number via the web and follow the instructions.

page.name: system-for-award-management-sam
page.title: System for Award Management (SAM)
page.body:
The Central Contractor Registration (CCR)/Federal Agency Registration (FedReg), the Online Representations and Certifications Applications (ORCA), and several other databases have been integrated into a single system to create a streamlined process for entities to register with the Federal Government, (formerly CCR/FedReg), and complete representations and Certifications (formerly ORCA). The System for Award Management, or SAM, is now the primary registrant database for the U.S. Federal Government. SAM collects, validates, and stores entity data in support of Agency Acquisition missions. A vendor must be registered with SAM prior to the Award of a Schedule Contract. Additionally, a DUNS number is required when registering with SAM.

Registering with SAM (SAM)

To register with SAM you must first create a User Account. Note that if you were previously registered with CCR and ORCA, your old login will not work in this system.

  1. Go to the SAM homepage: https://www.sam.gov/portal/public/SAM/.

  2. Click 'Create User Account.'

    3. Key Concept: The term "entity" is new in the realm of Federal Contracting. SAM is an integrated system with which several user communities interface, including vendors, Grantees, and Federal Agencies. In order to identify these varied users by one name, with regard to SAM, GSA refers to these users as "entities."

    On the System For Award Management (SAM) homepage, click 'Create User Account.'

  3. Next, you will be prompted to choose either an Account type. Under Individual Account Details, choose 'Create an Account.'

    4. Click 'Create an Account.'

  4. Follow the on-screen directions and fill out the Personal Information form fields. Click 'Next' to continue.

    5. Fill in your Personal Information.

  5. Next, complete the Account Information fields; this will include choosing a new username. It is important to note that once this username is created, it cannot be changed. After you are finished, click 'Next.'

    6. Fill in the Account Information.

  6. The next screen offers you a chance to review the data that you have entered and finalize the account creation. When you are ready to proceed, click 'Submit.' Unfortunately, the screens to show this step are too long to include. You may visit www.sam.gov and click the Help link to access a library of demonstration videos specific to SAM.

  7. Lastly, a screen will appear that confirms your account creation. An email will be sent to the address that you specified, detailing further instructions for completing the account creation process. Note that you must complete the confirmation process within 48 hours; after that, the entire process will need to be restarted.

    8. The confirmation screen.

  8. Click 'Done' to return to the SAM homepage where you may log in to the system after completing the final validation.

page.name: pathway-to-success-training
page.title: Pathway to Success Training
page.body:
Pathway to Success is designed to assist prospective GSA Schedule Contractors in making informed business decisions as to whether obtaining a GSA Schedule Contract is in their best interest. The presentation provides background information on the GSA Schedules Program and encompasses a variety of other topics including:

  1. GSA's expectations for a vendor to become a successful Schedule Contractor.

  2. Competing as a GSA Schedule Contractor in the government marketplace.

  3. Developing a GSA Schedule-specific business plan.

  4. Submitting a quality Offer, the Proposal submission process, and the GSA Schedule Solicitation.

Vendors may attend either a live presentation or complete web-based training at the vendor Support Center by visiting, http://vsc.gsa.gov, and selecting the Education tab.

The GSA vendor Support website.

page.name: logging-in
page.title: Logging In
page.body:
Once you have fulfilled all of the previously discussed requirements, you are ready to begin using the system. The homepage for eOffer and eMod is located at www.eoffer.gsa.gov.

When you go to the site you will find the Sign In buttons to the two systems on the right-hand side. Both systems have the same initial log in. For this example, we will assume this is the first time you have visited the site, and that you wish to log into the eOffer system.

  1. To begin, click on the Sign In button under Contract Offers (eOffers).

    2. Click the Sign In button under Contract Offers (eOffers).

    Key Concept: It is important to note at this point that users should not use the "Back" button in their web browsers. Doing so will cause data to be lost in the process. Use the buttons at the bottom of each screen, or click on different menu options to maneuver through the process.

  2. Upon first logging into the eOffer/eMod system, you will be required to verify your Digital Authentication Certificate. A dialogue box will open showing the existing Certifications on your system. Select the appropriate Certificate and click 'OK.'

    3. Verify your Digital Certificate.

  3. Click 'OK' on the Private Exchange Key or Windows Security pop-up screen to allow your browser to recognize your Certification.

  4. The sign in screen requires you to enter your Data Universal Numbering System (DUNS) number.

    1. If you have previously accessed the eOffer/eMod system, your DUNS number should be available from the dropdown menu in the Select previously entered DUNS field.

    2. If you have not previously used the eOffer/eMod system, you'll need to manually enter your DUNS number.

      3. Key Concept: The DUNS PLUS 4 field is optional. It is an extension of a DUNS number created by registrants in SAM when there is a need for more than one bank/Electronic Funds Transfer (EFT) account for a particular location. Basically the "DUNS plus 4" designation is used to identify specific business units within the overall organizational hierarchy.

      Enter your DUNS number.

  5. Click 'Submit' when finished entering in a new DUNS or selecting an appropriate, previously used DUNS number.

    6. Caution: If the DUNS number is incorrect or has expired an error message will display. You should contact the Federal Service Desk for SAM customer service at www.fsd.gov or 866-606-8220.

  6. Once the DUNS number has been validated the eOffer application will be accessed, displaying the MY eOFFERS page.

    7. This is the My eOffers page.

    Key Concept: The "My eOffers" screen serves as the entry point to the eOffer system. You can review all of the offers that have been processed to various extents, (Saved, Submitted, Signed).

page.name: preparing-your-electronic-contract-offer-eoffer-overview
page.title: Preparing Your Electronic Contract Offer (eOffer) Overview
page.body:
The web-based application eOffer allows Companies to electronically prepare and submit a Multiple Award Schedule (MAS) Contract Proposal to GSA's Federal Acquisition Service. It creates an interactive and secure electronic environment that simplifies the Contracting process from submission of Proposals all the way through Contract Award.

In the past, a vendor's submission of a Contract Offer relied heavily on paper-based processes. Vendors would print a bunch of forms, compile their Offers, and mail them in to GSA. Email helped expedite the process somewhat, but GSA still lacked a centralized system capable of handing the entirety of the Offer process.

eOffer, introduced in May 2004, has become the preferred method by which Contract Offers are submitted to GSA. This system is available for use on most of GSA's Multiple Award Schedules (MAS). With a friendly user interface and advanced functionality, eOffer has become an important tool for GSA as well as the vendor community.

page.name: preliminary-steps-before-using-the-system
page.title: Preliminary Steps Before Using the System
page.body:
The Offer process has several basic steps that must be completed outside of the system before you can use eOffer.

  1. Download and read the Solicitation that you are making an Offer against, and complete the required documents for that Solicitation. The Solicitations available for eOffers have recently been published to the system directly. You can access all of the solicitation documents here or by searching for them on FBO.gov.

  2. Gather your Company information and create the required documents for the Solicitation before starting to complete the information in eOffer. Once this has been done, you can enter the eOffer Application (which requires a Digital Certificate for authentication), prepare the responses to the Offer and submit your Proposal.

page.name: creating-a-contract-offer-eoffer
page.title: Creating a Contract Offer (eOffer)
page.body:
To sign into the eOffer application and create an Offer, follow these steps:

  1. Go to the GSA eOffer/eMod homepage.

  2. Click the Sign In button under Contract Offers (eOffers).

    3. Key Concept: The system is accessed via Digital Certificate authentication. For detailed login information, see the section on System Requirements to Access eOffer/eMod.

  3. After a successful login, the Sign In page will appear.

page.name: adding-your-negotiators
page.title: Adding Your Negotiators
page.body:
All users who need to access the system to work on a particular eOffer will need to be added as Authorized Negotiators. Multiple Negotiators may be added at one time, if necessary. The Negotiator's name and email address must be entered exactly as they appear on the individual's Digital Certificate.

Note that it is important to have more than one Negotiator assigned to a Contract. In the event that one Negotiator is unavailable, you will have another assigned to the Contract to ensure that a representative from your Company can still sign off on agreements with the government.

Additionally, as of February 2012, all Negotiators on a Contract have been provided "Global Read Capabilities." This means that no matter who has started a Contract Offer or Modification Request, an Authorized Negotiator will have the ability to create, submit, and edit offers and modification requests.

  1. To add a Negotiator, complete the mandatory fields as indicated by an asterisk (*), including Name, Title, Phone, and Email.

  2. Select a Role you want to assign to this Negotiator and click Add This Negotiator.

    3. Helpful Hint: A Negotiator can be assigned one of two roles; one denotes the Negotiator is authorized to sign and one denotes the Negotiator is not authorized to sign. A Negotiator who is "Authorized to Sign" is capable of providing his or her Digital Certificate for the benefit of any Offers or Mods. In essence, this person has been granted the authority to bind the Company into agreements with GSA. Someone who is not authorized to sign, however, may prepare an Offer, but will not be allowed to sign or submit it. Note that there should be at least one Negotiator who is authorized to sign.

    Select the Role for your negotiator and click 'Add This Negotiator.'

  3. Once a Negotiator is added, he or she will be listed under Your Negotiators. If you need to add another Negotiator, click Add New Negotiator and repeat the steps above.

    4. Helpful Hint: Many Contractors rely on third party consultants to help prepare Offers. Note that it is up to you whether or not you want to grant signing authority to a consultant in this situation. It is not a determination made by GSA.

    Click 'Add New Negotiator' to add additional Negotiators.

page.name: entering-your-standard-responses
page.title: Entering Your Standard Responses
page.body:
video
video_library_page/example_library/eoffer/solicitation-clauses/https:%2F%2Fs3.amazonaws.com%2Felucid-demo-videos%2Feoffer_standard_responses.mp4

There are five specific questions that you must respond to in this section, each of which relate to various acts, programs, or administrative issues relating to your GSA Schedule Contract Offering. Though there is some information available on screen, in the text below we identify some of the important elements of each of the questions to which you are required to respond.

Disaster Recovery Purchasing Program

Under the Disaster Recovery Purchasing Program, state and local government entities may purchase a variety of Products and Services from Contracts Awarded under GSA Federal Supply Schedules to facilitate recovery from a major disaster, terrorism, or nuclear, biological, chemical, or radiological attack.

State and local government entities may use GSA Schedule Contracts to purchase Products and Services in advance of a major disaster declared by the president, as well as in the aftermath of an emergency event. State and local government entities are responsible for ensuring that the Products or Services purchased are to be used to facilitate recovery.

By selecting Yes to participation in the Disaster Recovery Purchasing Program, your Company becomes eligible to provide Products or Services in the event of a disaster.

Exceptions to Terms and Conditions

The "Exceptions To Terms and Conditions" question asks whether or not you agree to all the standard terms and conditions described in the Solicitation package. While reading through the Solicitation documents, you should have noted whether there was anything you did not agree with. If you found a particular clause or term that was not to your liking, you should open a new document, identify the term, and provide your rationale as to why you are taking an exception to the term.

Exceptions to ORCA Certs and Reps

The "Orca Certs and Reps" question confirms that your information in ORCA is up to date. If there have been any changes to your Company information (such as a change in company size, NAICS, etc.), you should answer 'No' and provide information to GSA as to why you have done so.

Participation in ARRA

The American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 provided GSA with several billion dollars for investments in Federal buildings, procurement of more energy-efficient motor vehicles, and additional funding for the GSA Inspector General to provide oversight to the GSA Programs and Projects funded by the Recovery Act. With its implementation, new clauses have been added to the Contract. You must choose whether or not you agree to these clauses.

Participation in E-Verify

The Employment Eligibility Verification or "E-Verify" is an Internet-based system that allows an employer-using information reported on an employee's Form I-9 (Employment Eligibility Verification)-to determine the eligibility of that employee to work in the United States. This new system allows you to certify online whether or not all of your employees are eligible to work in the U.S.

  1. Respond to all the listed questions and click Save Response.

    2. Enter your standard responses.

  2. When the Information Saved message appears, click Continue.

    3. Click 'Continue' at the Information Saved message.

  3. You will continue on to the Responding to Solicitation Clauses section.

page.body:

  1. In the Commercial Sales Practice row, click on the Respond link in the Actions column.

    2. Click on the Respond link corresponding to the Commercial Sales Practice template.

  2. For Question 1a, enter a dollar figure that reflects the the total sales of the product or service during the previous 12-month period or during the last fiscal year.

  3. For Question 1b, designate the 12-month period for which you are providing the dollar figure. If you feel that the dollar figure is not an appropriate measure for sales, provide your own measure of the sales of the item(s) in the free-form box.

  4. Use the free-form box in section Question 2b to add any additional notes or comments that may be helpful to your CO.

    5. Enter your total projected annual sales to the Federal Government under the contract for the contract term, excluding all options, for each SIN.

  5. For Question 2a, the total projected annual sales to the Federal Government under the contract for the contract term, excluding all options, will be pre-populated for each SIN. This information is pulled from the Goods/Services > Add SIN(s) screen. To change this information, return to this screen and click on the Edit link in the Actions column.

    6. The total projected annual sales to the Government under the contract for each SIN offered will be pre-populated.

  6. Use the free-form box in section Question 2b to add any additional notes or comments that may be helpful to your CO.

  7. Question 3 asks you if, based on your discount policies, your prices are as good or better than prices offered to any other customer acquiring the same items, regardless of quantity or terms and conditions. Click Yes or No accordingly.

    8. Identify whether the concessions you offer the Government are equal to or better than the best price offered to customers.

  8. The next step is to identity the level at which you want to specify the discount or concession policy. This can be done at an Offer/Contract level or specified down to the individual SIN. In the case of line item EAS Schedules, those can be specified down to the line item level.

    9. Select the level at which you want to specify the discount/concession policy.

  9. Question 4a allows you to specify the details of your discount policy, and the options here change depending on whether you have selected a discount/concession policy based on the Offer/Contract level or the SIN level. First, though, you must work through the initial information on this screen. Upon saving, you will be able to enter further details.

    10. Fill out this first page and save it before adding details to your Discount Policy.

  10. In Question 4b, answer whether or not any deviations from your written policies or standard CSP disclosed in 4a ever resulted in better discounts (lower prices) or concessions than indicated.

    1. If you answer Yes, include the following:

      • discussion on any situations that lead to deviations from standard practice

      • an explanation of how often they occur

      • the controls you employ to assure the integrity of your pricing

        • Helpful Hint: Examples of typical deviations may include, but are not limited to: one-time goodwill discounts to charity organizations or to compensate an otherwise disgruntled customer; a limited sale of obsolete or damaged goods; the sale of sample goods to a new customer; or the sale of prototype goods for testing purposes.

    2. If deviations from your written policies or standard commercial sales practices disclosed in the chart on the Commercial Sales Practices Format are so significant and/or frequent that the Contracting Officer cannot establish whether the price(s) offered is fair and reasonable, then you may be asked to provide additional information. The Contracting Officer may ask for information to demonstrate that you have made substantial sales of the item(s) in the commercial market consistent with the information reflected on the chart on the Commercial Sales Practice Format, a description of the conditions surrounding those sales deviations, or other information that may be necessary in order for the Contracting Officer to determine whether your offered price(s) is fair and reasonable. In cases where additional information is requested, the Contracting Officer will target the request in order to limit the submission of data needed to establish the reasonableness of the offered price.

  11. When you have completed all fields, click Save.

    12. Answer the question on deviations.

  12. The screen will update whether you have chosen to specify your discount/concession policy at the Offer/Contract level or at the SIN level.

    13. Choose the option that is the basis for your proposed GSA price.

    1. If you chose the Offer/Contract level, you can specify your discount in terms of a discount or a markup/build-out.

    2. A discount is, plainly, a discount from the original price

    3. A markup is based on the markup over cost (e.g. a 5% markup over the manufacturer's catalog price). This is common for dealer/resellers. Imagine your company is a dealer/reseller of widgets. The manufacturer catalog price that you pay for the widgets is $10 per widget. The price you are offering GSA is a 5% markup on the price you pay the manufacturer, or $10.50.

    4. A build-out is derived from a buildup of individual costs. Your proposed GSA price is derived by totaling the individual cost elements that it takes to produce your product or service, and then adding an amount for profit. Profit, or fee, is usually expressed as a percentage of the cost elements. Your GSA proposed price will typically be a reduced profit or fee applied to the cost elements (e.g. labor + general & administrative + overhead + 5% profit = proposed GSA labor rate).

  13. Click Update Basis.

    14. Select your basis and click Update Basis.

  14. You will be taken to a screen to select the basis for your policy with more detailed descriptions of your options. Choose your basis and click Save.

  15. If your discount policy is at the SIN level, you will be able to define the basis for each SIN discount policy. You will see your SINs listed below. Click Update Basis to continue.

    16. Click Update Basis.

  16. For each SIN, you will be able to choose whether the basis for the CSP is Discount or Markup/Build-out. Make your choices and click Save.

    17. Select your basis and click Save.

  17. You will be taken back to the updated CSP creation screen. You will now be able to add your discount policy. If you wish to change the level of your specificity on your discount policy, you may click Update Level, otherwise click Add Discount Policy to enter your discount/concession information.

    18. Click Add Discount Policy.

  18. You will be taken to the Discount Policy / Concession Terms interface to enter your policy details. Note that if you selected a SIN or Line Item Policy, you will be able to specify which ones to which the discount applies; these fields will be absent for an Offer/Contract level discount policy.

    19. Discount Policy / Concession Terms Page

  19. Use the following information to complete each column of the chart:

    • Customer: Customer is the customer (i.e., Company XYZ) or category of customer (i.e., dealers, distributors, State, County, City and Local Governments, etc.) who receive the terms being disclosed.

    • Discount: Provide any basic discount offered this customer. A basic discount is any discount offered without regard for quantity (i.e., for a quantity of one). If you do not offer any basic discounts, insert "NONE".

    • Quantity/Volume: Provide any quantity or volume discounts offered this customer. For example, a discount of 10% is offered when 20+ units are purchased, OR a discount of 10% is offered when the net order exceeds $20,000.00. This discount is exclusive of any Basic Discount offered.

    • FOB Terms: Provide the FOB Terms (Freight Terms) offered this customer. For example, FOB Origin (Plant), FOB Origin Freight Prepaid and Allowed, or FOB Destination.

    • Concessions: Provide any other terms or conditions, not previously listed, which are offered to this category of customer. For example, any prompt-payment terms, aggregate discount terms, enhanced or additional services offered, etc.

    • More detailed instructions and information can also be found by clicking the link directly above question 4 on the CSP-1.

    The link about question 4a has a wealth of information on your CSP.

  20. When you are finished, click Save to return to the main CSP page.

  21. You will now see the discount policy information added to the Discount Policy table, where you can Edit or Delete the policy as needed.

    22. Your discount policy has been added.

  22. If applicable, you may also add multiple policies by clicking Add Discount Policy.

    23. You can add multiple discount policies.

  23. When you are satisfied with your Commercial Sales Practice, click Save under the textbox provided in 4b.

    24. When you are satisfied with your CSP, click Save.

page.name: justifying-your-clause-exceptions
page.title: Justifying Your Clause Exceptions
page.body:
If you recall from the Standard Response section, you were asked whether or not you were taking any exceptions to the standard Terms and Conditions. If you did not take any exceptions in the previous Standard Responses section, skip the next section, Clause Exceptions, and move on to the Upload Documents. However, If you answered 'Yes' to Exceptions to Terms and Conditions, follow the steps below:

  1. You will be presented with a list of contract clauses for taking exception(s). Select the Regulation(s) for which you are taking exceptions by clicking the check box. Then click the Select Regulations button.

    2. Select the Clause against which you wish to take an exception, then click 'Select Regulation.'

    Helpful Hint: If you need to view the clause you can click on the Clause Number which is given as a link. The clause body will open up in a separate window as a PDF.

  2. On the next screen you will see an Exceptions Text box as well as the Excerpt From Clause box. Notice that now you have an Exceptions section in your eOffer menu on the left. Review the Instructions. To view the clause click on the Clause link.

    3. Click the Clause number link when you are ready to select your text

  3. The clause body will open up as a pdf file. Highlight and copy (Ctrl+C) the text for which the exception is being taken (as demonstrated below).

    4. A PDF will open up, select and copy the text against which you wish to take exception.

  4. Click in the Excerpt From Clause box and press press (Ctrl+V). The text will get copied. Click the Ready To Edit button. A pop up will display. Click OK.

    5. Paste your text into the Excerpt from Clause box and click Ready to Edit

page.name: subcontracting-plan
page.title: Subcontracting Plan
page.body:
video
video_library_page/example_library/eoffer/subcontracting-plan/https:%2F%2Fs3.amazonaws.com%2Felucid-demo-videos%2Feoffer_subk_overview.mp4

In the Standard Response section, you were required to answer questions with regard to a Subcontracting Plan. The decision tree will determine if your business is required to submit a Subcontracting Plan as a result of that input.

Helpful Hint: If your input in the Subcontracting Plan decision tree under Standard Responses resulted in no required Subcontracting plan, skip this section and move on to Upload Documents. However, if you qualify for a plan, this section will need to be completed.

This is an example in which a Subcontracting Plan is not required.

This is an example in which a Subcontracting Plan is required

A Subcontracting Plan is required on a Contract under certain situations. Generally, the Federal Acquisition Regulations (FAR) require a Subcontracting Plan from a Contractor classified as "Other than Small Business," when the actual Sales of a Contract exceed the $650,000 threshold or $1,500,000 for construction.

  1. You will be presented with options for the creation or upload of your Subcontracting Plan. If you already have a Subcontracting Plan, choose from the first set of options that will allow you to upload either a Master, or Commercial Plan. If you do not have a Subcontracting Plan, the second option will guide you through the steps to create one. Select either Individual Plan or Commercial Plan then click Save Plan Type.

    2. Select the Subcontracting Plan type.

    Key Concept:Commercial Plans cover a vendor's fiscal year and apply to the entire production of commercial items sold by either the entire Company or a portion there of. They apply both to commercial and government business, and affect all government Contracts in that applicable year. Individual Plans cover an entire Contract period and apply to one Contract specifically.

  2. After selecting which Subcontracting Plan you wish to create, you will see an overview screen with each subsection of the Subcontracting Plan and its status. For the purpose of this walk-through, we will follow an Individual Plan. To begin, click 'Respond' on the line corresponding to the first section, Identification Data.

    3. Click the Respond button on the line corresponding to the Identification Plan section.

  3. Enter a detailed description of your Supplies/Services in the textbox. Next enter your Place of Performance, and then the Estimated Contract Value covering the Base Period and all of the Option Periods. Before you click 'Next,' press the Save button.

    4. Enter a Description and Estimated Contract Values.

  4. The Goals section is where you state the percent of the Contract value that you intend to designate for the various Subcontracting categories. Begin by clicking 'Add' under the action column.

    5. Click the Add link under your Base period goals.

  5. You will need to enter the Total Dollars to be Subcontracted, which will be the sum of the Subcontracting Goals for both Large Businesses and All Small Businesses. When filling out the Large Business goals, you will find the system will automatically complete either the percentage or dollar amount, depending on which you choose to fill out. This will help you along the way ensure you are doing the proper math and that everything adds up.

    6. Fill in your Base Period Subcontracting Goals.

  6. Next, fill in the Small Business Type goals. These goals should be considered independently, not as values that equal your goals for All Small Businesses. As there may be instances in which Subcontractors qualify for multiple designations, each of the Small Business types could add up beyond the total of the All Small Businesses goals. When you are finished, click 'Save,' then click 'Next' to move on.

    7. Fill in your Small Business Type Subcontracting Goals before continuing.

  7. You will see the Subcontracting values reflected in the Goals chart. If you wish to fill any subsequent Option period with the same goals as the Base period, click the Copy link. Otherwise skip to step 15 below.

    8. If applicable, you can copy your goals from the Base period to fill in subsequent Option periods.

  8. The Base period's values will be copied to the Option periods you select. When you have made your selections click 'Copy,' then click 'Next.'

    9. If applicable, select the periods to which you want to copy your Base Period Small Business Type Goals.

  9. The Goals chart will now have matching values wherever you have chosen to replicate the Base period's values. You also have the ability to Edit or Delete each Option period.

    10. You will now be able to see replicated goals reflected in the Goals table

  10. To select which Supplies or Services are to be Subcontracted, click the Add button.

    11. Click 'Add' to select which Supplies or Services are to be Subcontracted.

  11. Identify the Supply or Service to be Subcontracted and select which type of Subcontractor will be leveraged. When you have finished, click 'Save' before continuing to add other entries as needed. When you are finished, click 'Next.'

    12. Enter the Supply or Services and their applicable designations.

  12. The List of Supplies or Services will now display your entries and corresponding eligible Subcontracting types with the ability to Edit or Delete each entry.

    13. The Services or Supplies are now displayed in the Services/Supplies table.

  13. Next-using evidence from historical data, experience, or research-explain how your goals were established and justify any particularly low goals in Section C.

    14. Explain how your goals were established and justify any particularly low goals.

  14. Enter a detailed description on how your Company plans to identify potential partners to meet your Subcontracting goals in Section D.

    15. Enter a detailed description of how your Company plans to identify potential partners to meet your Subcontracting goals

  15. Finally, in Section E, state whether indirect costs have been included in the Subcontracting goals. If they have been accounted for, explain the methodology used to calculate these costs in the textbox below. When you are finished click 'Save,' then click 'Next.'

    16. State whether indirect costs have been included in the Subcontracting goals. Account for the calculation, then click 'Save' to move on.

  16. You will be taken to the Program Administrator screen. You cannot add this information directly into the Subcontracting Plan utility, rather it is added to the Solicitation Clauses section. The Subcontracting Plan generates the associated points of contact there. Click the Solicitation Clauses link on the left-side navigation menu.

    17. Click the Solicitation Clauses link on the left-side navigation menu to enter your Admin Point of Contact.

  17. On the Solicitation Clauses screen, you will notice the addition of the Point of Contacts Information entry. Click the Respond link in the Actions column.

    18. Click the Respond link for Point of Contact Information.

  18. Select 'Contact for Subcontracting Plan' from the dropdown menu and click 'Add Point of Contact Details.'

    19. Select the contact for the SubContracting Plan from the dropdown menu.

  19. Fill out the Administrator's contact information.

    20. Enter the contact information for the Administrator.

    Helpful Hint: While not required, it is a good idea to also add an alternate contact for your Subcontracting Plan.

  20. After adding your Subcontracting Plan Point of Contact and an alternate Point of Contact,click 'SubContracting Plan' in the left-side navigation menu in order to return to the Subcontracting Plan screen.

    21. Click the SubContracting Plan link on the left-side navigation menu.

  21. You will notice that Point of Contact details are now displayed.

    22. You will notice Point of Contact details are now displayed.

  22. Next, you will need to identify the duties of the the Subcontracting Plan Administrator. One through five are required by the FAR. Select the applicable functions, meant to ensure effective implementation of the Subcontracting Plan. Identify any additional measures in the textbox at the end of the list. When you are finished click 'Save,' then click 'Next' to continue.

    23. Select the applicable Subcontracting Plan Administrator duties.

  23. The Equitable Opportunity section summarizes your businesses efforts to ensure Equitable Opportunity and Competition for small business, including outreach efforts and internal Programs designed for purchasing personnel. Check all applicable boxes and describe any additional efforts in the textbox provided. Click 'Save' before clicking 'Next' to move on.

    24. Select the applicable Equitable Opportunities your business plans to pursue

  24. The Clause Inclusion and Flow Down section contains the assurance that all Subcontracts in excess of $650,000 ($1,500,000 for construction) adopt a plan which Offers further Subcontracting opportunities. You must first agree to this by checking the box, then click 'Save' before clicking 'Next' to move on.

    25. Check the box agreeing to Assurances of Clause Inclusion and Flow Down

  25. The Reporting and Cooperation section contains assurances required by FAR that all Contractors will submit various forms of Reports, including a timetable for Individual Subcontract Reports. All Contractors must agree to these conditions. Confirm your agreement by clicking the check box, then click 'Save' before clicking 'Next.'

    26. Check the box agreeing to Reporting and Cooperation measures.

  26. In the Record Keeping section, confirm your intent to maintain Records throughout the course of the Subcontracting Plan. Provide evidence of your ability to comply with Record Keeping standards using the text box following number 7 of this section. Click 'Save and Continue' when you are finished.

    27. Agree to Record Keeping standards, provide evidence of your ability, then click 'Save and Continue' when you are finished.

  27. In the Statutory Requirements section, confirm your intent to comply with FAR requirements, then click 'Save and Continue.'

    28. Confirm your intent to comply with FAR requirements, then click 'Save and Continue.'

  28. The final section is the Good Faith Effort. You must give a detailed outline of the steps your Company plans to take to achieve your Subcontracting goals in good faith. When you have finished click 'Save.' Save.

    29. Briefly describe the actions your Company will take to meet its Subcontracting goals in Good Faith.

  29. Once you have finished the Good Faith Effort section, you will see a message saying your progress has been saved successfully. In order to continue, use the navigation on the left to proceed to the Upload Documents section.

    30. Choose 'Upload Documents' from the Navigation menu on the left.

page.name: uploading-your-documents

The Upload Documents screen allows you to provide additional supporting documentation to the offer. This is the final step prior to submission. By the time you get to this screen, you should have already completed all of the required documents and have them ready to upload. If you have not, however, you can view the solicitation document by clicking the "View PDF" link to get more information on any of the necessary documents that you still need to complete.

page.name: submitting-your-eoffer
page.title: Submitting Your eOffer

page.name: preparing-an-electronic-contract-modification-emod
page.title: Preparing an Electronic Contract Modification (eMod)
page.body:
eMod is a web-based application that allows vendors to submit their Multiple Award Schedule (MAS) contract modification requests electronically (eMods). eMod uses the digital authentication technology in order to ensure the integrity of data, and provides electronic signature capability. A digital certificate is required in order to use eMod. See the section on Digital Certificates for more details.

Using eMod, a vendor can submit multiple mods within a single transaction. Different type(s) of mods and their associated subtypes can be selected. Another feature of eMod allows GSA contracting personnel to "split" mods. For example, a Contracting Officer (CO) has the ability to perform a split if one of the mods can be done quickly, but the other mod action may require more time to complete.

Rather than waiting for both mods to be completed at the same time, splitting the mod expedites the process.

Key Concept: While the following discussion outlines the process of a vendor- submitted contract modification, a GSA Contract Officer (CO) or Contract Specialist (CS) is able to issue unilateral mods that do not require vendor confirmation.

page.name: getting-started-with-emod

    4. Confirm your digital certificate.

  4. Select the appropriate DUNS number using the drop-down or manually enter it in the text box and click Submit.

    5. Select your DUNS.

  5. On the next screen, select the contract number from the dropdown that needs to be modified, and click the Select Contract button.

    6. Select your contract

  6. At this time, the My Modifications page will be visible where you can create new Mods, work on saved ones, or edit submitted ones.

page.name: creating-an-emod

page.body:
video
video_library_page/example_library/emod/getting-started-with-emod/https:%2F%2Fs3.amazonaws.com%2Felucid-demo-videos%2Femod_creating_emod.mp4

Creating an eMod is the bread and butter of the eMod system. In the following steps, we will show you how to navigate the system to modify your existing MAS contract. In fact, we will show you how to submit a mod for each of the modification Primary Types and Subtypes.

From the "My Modifications" home page, you can see all of the saved, submitted, and signed modifications. You can create a new eMod (as described below) or edit an existing one. Note that if you are opting to edit an existing modification, a new "Lock" functionality has been introduced that may not allow you to work on a submission. If a modification has been locked, there will be a "closed lock" icon next to it. If a user wishes to edit a submitted modification, they can request to unlock the mod by clicking the "Edit Mod" button. If the mod is already unlocked, a user can edit the modification just by clicking the "Edit Mod" button.

  1. Click the drop-down box under New Modifications, select the appropriate contract number, and click the Select Contract button.

    2. Select your contract from the dropdown menu then click 'Select Contract.'

page.name: pricing-modifications-overview
page.title: Pricing Modifications Overview
page.body:
Pricing modifications allow organizations to accurately document increases and decreases in the prices of their products of services. Whether influenced by the economic climate or changes in production, accurate prices are critical to the procurement of a various services.

These are the Pricing Modifications

The following rules apply to the pricing modifications:

  • Both Temporary Price and Permanent Price Reduction cannot be selected at the same time.

  • If Permanent Price Reduction is selected the vendor must select either (A) Permanent price reduction (based on most favored customer) or (B) Permanent Price Reduction (industry partner requested).

  • Similarly both Economic Price Adjustments cannot be selected at the same time. The vendor must select either (A) Economic Price Adjustments (EPA) with commercial price list (increase) or (B) Economic Price Adjustments (EPA) without commercial price list (increase).

If any of the above-mentioned rules are violated the following error message will be displayed.

Pricing modification selection error

    Click 'Yes' on the Information Saved screen.
